Award.AwardTitle: An Introduction to Careers in Polar Sciences for Young Women
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Principal Investigator proposes a series of field courses for teenage young women with the theme of Glaciers, Climate, and the Alpine Landscape to provide them with an immersion-science experience that has four goals for students:

?to increase young women?s interest in pursuing science as a career
?to create life-long advocates for the scientific process
?to teach critical thinking skills
?to enhance their leadership self-confidence so that they have a higher likelihood of becoming
community leaders in the future.

This series of courses will build on a highly successful program, Girls on Ice (http://girlsonice.org), which the PI has been leading for nearly 10 years and which provides young women with strong, female role models; with an opportunity to see what a career in the Earth sciences is like; with one-on-one interactions with scientists; with facilitated discussions on the value of Earth science in societal issues; and with challenges that will build their self-confidence in multiple ways.

To ensure that the young women who experience Girls on Ice maintain their new self-confidence and inspiration, the PI will create a peer-mentoring program (primarily through on-line methods) such that older Girls on Ice participants can mentor younger ones through their last years of high school and entering college. Participants will also be required to give a presentation and lead a discussion with young women at their high school after they return.

Furthermore, the PI will lead two graduate student workshops to provide training and experience
in field teaching. The graduate students who participate will not only have opportunities to lead Girls on
Ice and Alaska Summer Research Academy courses, but also will give them valuable skills for their
future academic career.

This proposal includes a formal program evaluation and assessment that includes a four-year longitudinal study of one cohort of Girls on Ice participants as they go through the transitional period at the end of high school.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research shows that many girls are interested in the sciences at an early age, but drift away when they reach their teens because of societal norms and expectations for girls. Girls are surrounded by messages -- from movies and advertising to comments from teachers or other adults --  to  underestimate their intellectual and  physical capabilities. This barrage of messaging leads girls to underestimating themselves.

To counter this effect, we developed and led a series of wilderness-based expeditions for teenage girls modeled after authentic scientific research expeditions. These tuition-free expeditions are designed to reignite girls' interest in and their confidence for science and scientific thinking. They learn that scientific thinking stems from their natural ability to observe and be curious and is an integral part of all aspects of daily life.  The expeditions teams are diverse and inclusive of girls from all backgrounds and interests. The mentor-instructors include professional scientists and artists who guide girls through observing, questioning, designing experiments, and discovering new ideas about the world around them.  Girls on Ice expeditions are tuition free because we believe ALL girls deserve an opportunity to challenge themselves, be curious, and build their confidence and empower them to choose science as a major in college and as a career. 

The wilderness environment pushes them outside of their comfort zone, where they learn to trust their physical abilities while learning to live and work as a team. Along the way they develop intensive new friends and find valuable role models and mentors in the instructors and their teammates. 
By leveraging this NSF award, we

1. Offered 16 expeditions fully or partially funded through this award and supported development of five others. These expeditions provided 200 girls with this life-changing experience.

2. Ran five leadership training workshops and supplemental mentoring that provided scientific teaching and research leadership skills for over 50 early career scientists (graduate students, post docs, faculty) along with another 10 professional artists and wilderness guides.\item Mentored early career scientists towards development of six new expeditions using the Girls on Ice educational model: Girls on Ice Alaska, Switzerland, Canada; Girls in Icy Fjords; Girls on Rock; and Girls on Water. 

3. Conducted education research showing 

* that our model helps girls overcome a major hurdle for entering field-based scientific research by helping them learn the "invisible" aspects of the scientific process and cultural norms for living on a field team that can be a barrier to entering science careers (Conner et al, 2017). 

* how living on a glacier and conducting research changes the girls'  perception of and understanding of glacier change, its connection to climate change science and related environmental changes, and their potential to contribute to future societal understanding or mitigation efforts (Young et al, in prep).

Ultimately, the results of this award include providing 200 teenage girls -- from all socio-economic backgrounds -- a life-changing experience that stimulated their courage, confidence, and interest in science. They the power of curiosity to take active ownership of their own learning, instead of search the internet for an answer. Their personal success on these expeditions lead them to be more curious in the future, in all aspects of their life. 

More broadly, the visibility and discourse Girls on Ice has generated  among both the public and the scientific community helps everyone visualize a scientific community that is inclusive and accessible to all, including people of color and others traditionally underrepresented in the sciences. 

"I can do what I want to do, if I believe in myself I can do it. We climbed a glacier [thousands of] feet in the sky, that was pretty amazing and I don?t think I would have ever believed I could have done that without this program. It was funny and memorable, and difficult and hard but I loved every moment of it."K'sana, British Columbia, Girls on Ice Cascades 2017

"[Girls On Ice] truly changed my life as it opened my horizons to this wonderful world and stored faith and confidence into myself to apply to a school like Mount Holyoke and dreams to become a woman in STEM... " Destiny, Florida, Girls on Ice Cascades 2015.

"Let me say, WOW.Brooke grew so much and learned so much as she was part of the Mount Baker expedition this summer." Parent of Brooke, West Virginia, Girls on Ice Cascades 2017

"After viewing them through a scientist?s lens, I now realize the glaciers? significance to biological communities, how much there still is to discover about them, and how important it is to preserve these natural wonders. For me, this is only the tip of the iceberg. As I continue to pursue my passion for science, I hope to instill in others a commitment to environmental conservation and the will to explore." Meixi, Kansas, Girls on Ice Cascades 2011

  • Girls on Ice Cascades is the originally designed expedition. This 12-day experience includes an 8 day mountaineering expedition on Mount Baker in Washington State with a scientific emphasis on the interactions among changing glaciers, active volcanoes, and the high alpine ecological environment.

  • Girls on Ice Alaska was developed in 2012 by three grad students at UAF with mentoring from PI Pettit following a similar same educational model and curriculum, but on Gulkana Glacier, one of the glaciers studied since the 1960s by the U.S. Geological Survey.
    Inspiring Girls Expeditions
    Erin C Pettit
    Girls on Ice Alaska
  • Through our leadership workshops, we developed several expeditions in new environments. Girls in Icy Fjords was the first new expedition, offered in 2017. These new expeditions use the educational philosophy, but with curriculum specific to the new environment.
    Inspiring Girls Expeditions
    Copyrighted
    Erin C Pettit
    Girls in Icy Fjords
  • The technical skills in mountaineering and wilderness travel the girls learn provides them with self-efficacy not only for traveling in this environment, but also for learning new skills that are typically not expected of teenage girls.
    Inspiring Girls Expeditions

    Inspiring Girls Technical Skill Building
  • Scientific research is the core of Girls on Ice. Girls spend the first three days conducting instructor-inspired projects. Then in teams of three, they ask their own questions, design their own experiment, interpret their data, and give a public presentation after coming out of the wilderness.
